required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Morbidity, Mortality and Gender Differences in Patients With Pacemakers
clinical_study.official_title: Morbidity, Mortality and Gender Differences in Patients With Pacemakers; a Large-scale Single-center Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Previous publications suggest gender difference in outcome parameters after pacemaker implantation. Aim of this study is to investigate gender differences in patients with pacemaker. Implanted devices, indication for implantation and pacemaker follow up data of patients will be included. Survival data including cause of death will be documented. Prevalent comorbidities and relevant laboratory data will be recorded.

primary_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: There is no survival difference between women and men after pacemaker Implantation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Implantation rates of single- or dual-chamber Pacemaker in women/men.
secondary_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: Women and men have equal implantation rates of single- and dual-chamber pacemakers.

secondary_outcome.measure: Survival of women/men after single- or dual-chamber pacemaker implantation.
secondary_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: Survival after single- or dual-chamber pacemaker implantation is equal.

other_outcome.measure: First implantation age in single- or dual-chamber pacemaker
other_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: There is no difference in first implantation age between sexes and single- or dual-chamber pacemakers.
Null hypothesis: There is no difference between women and men in time to device- or lead-replacement.

other_outcome.time_frame: Survival analysis: 10 years; data obtained: March 2nd, 2016
other_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: There is no difference in survival and first pacemaker implantation when selected comorbidity was found.

other_outcome.measure: Survival and device/lead-replacement in patients with diabetes.
other_outcome.description: Null hypothesis: There is no difference in survival or device/lead-replacement rates in women/men with diabetes.
Null hypothesis: There is no difference between women and men in pacing threshold and lead impedance.
Null hypothesis: There is no difference between women and men in troponin T, N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic Peptide, HbA1c and low-density lipoprotein.

arm_group.description: Patients with implanted cardiac pacemaker registered in pacemaker database of the Department of Cardiology at the Medical University Vienna were included.

study_pop.textblock: Women and men with implanted cardiac Pacemaker and at least one follow up in our Pacemaker Office of the Department of Cardiology at the Medical University Vienna. Patients were enrolled regardless of time and place of pacemaker implantations.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients registered in the pacemaker database of the Department of Cardiology at the Medical University Vienna. Patients get registered when clinical follow up of an implanted Pacemaker is done.
Exclusion Criteria:
- For survival analysis: No valid match of first name AND surname AND date of birth with patients' insurance data.
- For analysis of comorbidities: Not a single documented diagnose was found in our electronic clinic-wide patients' information system.
